1016829786910388224.text:
Decentralization = Distribution of Power and Control

You can distribute your architecture across as many different layers and entities as you want, but if authority is concentrated in a single entity then the system is centralized.

1105199418486202369.text: 12) Thanks for reading. This will probably end up being a larger blog post at some point in time as these all continue to develop.

1105199416997306369.text: 11) Displacement narratives are a net positive because they may lead to the creation of better systems and better incentives (token displacement), better products (decentralization displacement), and even test new decisionmaking processes in contained environments (governance).

1105199415915106305.text: 10) Although it's difficult to measure the success of these systems, they're hard to compare to the rigidity and antifragility that Bitcoin has generated over time from the decisionmaking process it has adhered to. This displacement narrative may need more time to develop.

1105199412970688512.text: 9) Lastly, governance displacement deals with the theatrics associated with projects experimenting with token governance, on-chain governance, or any deviation of the original "ungovernance" model of Bitcoin.pic.twitter.com/PneK7h4eXG

1105199411263619078.text: 8) The easiest examples of this include sidechain implementations, plasma implementations, and the projects that build on them. Smaller validator set centralizes things a bit, but allows easier transaction times and "meaningful" distribution rather than a single entity.

1105199409489428482.text: 7) Decentralization displacement deals primarily with degrees of "total trustlessness" being compromised for the sake of a better user experience and transaction times. Not all systems might need massive amounts of censorship resistance or blockchains for that matter.

1105199408247984131.text: 6) The latter involves the replacement of an asset to achieve an original vision, or test alternative incentives in an existing system where a token doesn't retain meaningful value. This is the case of @protocol_hydro and @0xProject.

1105199405085478916.text: 5) The former involves the removal of an asset, and the greatest case of this is @UniswapExchange displacing @Bancor through a simple interface, and less friction. Bancor's exorbitant raise only damages its reputation at this point, and the team seems to have another ICO in mind.pic.twitter.com/XYi759SQk0

1105199404187897858.text: 4) Token displacement is a recent trend that also exists on two spectrums: removing a token for the sake of a better user experience, and challenging an existing token system in an open source system.

1105199401683898368.text: 3) However, they are complementary: the attention Bitcoin is given as a competitor to legacy fiat systems solidifies its status as the greatest store of value in the ecosystem. Though competitors have tried to remove its status, none have been successful to date.pic.twitter.com/SdCAjvZ6WF

1105199400392032257.text: 2) Monetary displacement exists on two spectrums: cryptocurrencies versus existing fiat systems, and cryptocurrencies challenging Bitcoin as a store of value.

1105199399406354433.text:
1) The idea of displacement has been a common narrative in the space - but sometimes it's quite important to highlight continual items: 

-Monetary displacement 
-Token displacement 
-Decentralization displacement 
-Governance displacement

1039855354623012864.text: 8) Alright I'm done ranting, just mentally preparing for a token conference.

1039855352592908288.text: 7) Also governance is futile if you're just adding some "bells and whistles" on something that only requires a demand side. Effective businesses shouldn't be pseudo-DAOifying.

1039855350646812672.text: 6) Also if you're trying to disguise a payments token as a "governance token" please don't. Governance should be a byproduct of larger incentive models - you need participants first before voting on anything.

1039855284351643648.text: 5) The first recommendation to anyone I give is don't tokenize. If what you're building truly scales as a larger layer, let's talk.

1039855267972833280.text: 4) If you're looking to add loyalty points, keep it on a central database - transactions are costly, and blockchains are clunky. If you're looking to add payments, use the base chain's currency - it costs more to move tokens, and there's a hurdle to bootstrap liquidity.

1039855254957944833.text: 3) If a network relies on participants to commit to a particular function in the network to keep it running, you need to incentivize them. If it's simply a business model that only requires a demand side, you probably don't need a token.

1039855225824268288.text: 2) However, the necessity for both abstraction and incentives comes with a few questions, namely, how flexible is what you're building?

1039855200645853184.text: 1) Tokens are both an effective way of abstracting value, and providing incentives for protocols built above a base chain.
